content.body: Hixie: you around?
Yay, finally in California!
's roadtrip has gone on far too long.
heya TabAtkins
Yo maciej.
Hixie: Thanks for combining all your replies based on their general topic. :)
Hixie: It would have been even better if you'd included the original subject before each quote, though. ;)
GPHemsley: unfortunately pine doesn't make that very easy :-(
So is that platform preview of IE9 installable next to IE8 or will it overwrite?
ah, looks like it can be installed side by side
We designed the Platform Preview to be installed, side by side with IE8. The Platform Preview is not a replacement for your daily browser; [...]
personal sites aren't WP:RS? Mine seems to be.
WP:RS?
asmodai: reputavble source for wikipedia
their notion of what is a reputable source always strikes me as confusing
hsivonen: Aye.
othermaciej: It's based on whatever whim some editor now has.

there's pages where a direct edit from me would be original research, my email to someone else would not be a reliable source, but me posting the same info on the webkit.org does count as a reliable source
http://desandro.com/resources/curtis-css-typeface/
Mmm, IE9 breaks down on the DOM attributes (Prototype) of dromaeo
can a window or window.document object be queried for its intent to navigate?
problem: I have a library method that takes a window object and tries to decide of the window object is done navigating and loading
if the window object came from window.open immediately before, it'll have about:blank in readyState "complete"
so it's indistinguishable from a window that intends to stay as about:blank
XML is still awesome: http://hsivonen.iki.fi/screen/visitmix-ysod.png
hsivonen: hehehe
Kuruma: I love the nickname :) 車ですね。。。
hsivonen: seems to be fixed now - I guess someone noticed?
Just another benefit of XML: when you have a minor irrelevant problem someone has to scramble to fix it urgently
XML probably made more sense when most content was static
did IE9 get a negative response in some quarters?
(I'm reading mollydotcom's twitter feed and it sounds defensive)
hsivonen: I get text/html on that page - how come it was XML?
So far I am impressed with IE9, there might be hope for MS on the standards front.
I also get a/h+x
*a/x+x
only in fx
was looking in Firefox 3.6
Do things like http://live.visitmix.com/search?term=cheese%01 break too?
(The cheese is probably unnecessary)
Philip`: yes: value="cheese"
3.7a4pre
renders a bit, then ysod with no text
I get text/html there too
Hmm, now http://live.visitmix.com/ gives me a YSOD
so it's not fixed yet
when using some version of Minefield/3.7a2pre
i guess now when ie will support xhtml, we'll get to see a lot more YSODs
Seems to be working reliably in my Firefox and failing reliably in my Minefield
(where "working" means "using text/html")
Someone should start a blog that collects YSODs on the sites of people who ought to know better
WFM in Opera + Chrome FFM in Minefield
installs UA switcher
Viewing the page in IE9, I get a script error dialog box
It gets sent text/html
(based on User-Agent sniffing)
whatwg cabal -- always breaking your interwebs
hah
annevk: Do you guys also fix intarwebs?
we try to fix part of the "foundation"
But mostly we just point and laugh
(or cry)
or shrug etc.
Philip`: Sometimes I think cry is the more appropriate reaction.
Then again, if I had to shed a tear for every abuse of the web standards I find I'd be a dried out husk by now.
annevk: 10.10 vs 10.50 -- 10.50 had a completely overhauled js engine or was it incremental.
asmodai: Completely new
Thankee
someone @ tweakers asking about the perf numbers
asmodai, version numbers are a game marketing plays that nobody understands, not even those involved
annevk: Hahaha, oh I know. Just wanted to enlighten somenoe.
annevk: http://tweakers.net/nieuws/66227/microsoft-zet-previewversie-internet-explorer-9-online.html
pretends to be annevk and understand that
When I commented there were no replies yet.
asmodai, ah, I guess the confusion in that thread is that our version numbers are like decimal numbers nowadays, confusingly different from what everyone else is doing
asmodai, though not everyone internally agrees they are like decimal numbers, making matters even more weird
fortunately we offer the latest version on opera.com and you don't have to pick one :)
Do like ATI and release Opera X1 next

so as far as i can tell, julian seems determined to trap hixie into stating that there will always be a group maintaining html within the organization that has been trying to kill and/or replace html since the day it was founded
which, when you say it out loud, does seem kind of silly
More like as long as anyone cares about HTML, there will be someone mainining HTML
And when nobody cares anymore, who cares? (Nobody)
Anyone, anyone, Bueller?
Maybe he's saying that, once hixie gets hit by a bus, the Serious Standards People promise to stop working on HTML. Again.
WHATWG is the prime example of this
which is certainly not outside the realm of possibility
w3c dropped the ball completely, but people still cared about HTML, so WHATWG was formed to continue the work
is pretty sure he knew that already :O
anyway, kind of a weird argument to be having
You know, maybe some of our viewer don't? :)
*viewers
but i suppose it's not nearly as weird as arguing over the normative reference to ASCII
or any of the myriad of other trivial things that julian chooses to spend his time arguing about
clearly he has a lot of spare time
But imagine the pain if a Serious Standard got the wrong normative reference to ASCII!
Can we clone Hixie?
We could breed him
Are you suggesting using Hixie like a stallion?
mpilgrim: I was quite surprised to see him arguing in favor of non-text non-ascii RFCs
oh, that rfc format discussion? yeah, it's scary to think that, in some circles, julian is the voice of reason
i see why he feels so frustrated in the HTMLWG
jgraham: I'm sure he'd like being a studmuffin.
UNICODE IS A CONSPIRACY TO BREAK OUR TOOLS AND STEAL OUR WOMEN
Dashiva: Doesn't seem that surprising given that he's written a tool to generate HTML versions of RFCs
AND MEN, AND NON-GENDER-SPECIFIC DOMESTIC PARTNERS
annevk: oh btw, the opera mini 5 beta (latest on the android market  place) doesn't seem to grok any MathML. So I doubt the released version has rudimentary support as you said yesterday
annevk: I'll be glad to be proven wrong though :D
I think they should have stuck with hand-written faxed RFCs
asmodai, we implement it via some CSS rules; I guess those are not included on the mini server
Do they still accept RFCs in that format?
That's the only technology that is sure to last for centuries, long after all our ASCII text tools have died out
What if English dies out?
asmodai, did you try Opera 10.50?
annevk: moment
fires up 10.50
Dashiva: Archeological linguists can rediscover it and then translate the RFCs
I get something like: S p = C p cos ⁡ i 1 - d + d + W ⁡ i cos⁡ s n
just like anything else, the only reason the IETF will ever change is if someone stands up to them
someone who has something they want
Which is the raw data in between the matml tags
like some emerging standard
annevk: So doesn't look like it does.
and says "no, fuck you and your 30-year-old formatting rules"
asmodai, got a link?
asmodai, chaals is interested
annevk: sure
annevk: http://www.in-nomine.org/~asmodai/3d.html
tim bray complained about this many times, because the IETF's ASCII-only formatting rules mandated misspelling the name of one of the atompub editors
and that can't be the first time that's happened
mpilgrim: whose name?
asmodai, ah yeah, we don't do the entities, but the rest doesn't look that great either :/
annevk: for all I know that should be html 5 compliant. hsivonen's validator only complains about the mathml elements, but that's because he's still working on adding that.
Bill de hÓra
ah
asmodai, aah, we only enable it for XML
annevk: Ach zo
annevk: Would that include the XHTML + MathML profile?
asmodai, hopefully
as you can tell I have not done a whole lot with this myself :)
actually, also asbjørn ulsberg's name is misspelled in rfc 4287
as in the transliteration of his name is wrong
(the proper substitute for ø (ø) is oe
But that's his own fault, apparently
annevk: yeah, looks like XHTML + MathML gets a better treatment
annevk: checked out my pre-conversion XHTML version: http://www.in-nomine.org/~asmodai/3d.xhtml
needs to double check these old formulae for consistency.
annevk: How well versed is chaals in MathML btw?
not sure
mpilgrim, btw, why the positive stance for H264? (it seems somewhat contradictory with the thing on Firefox icon licensing, though I realize it is not at all the same)
asmodai: it seems mathml entities don't work in o10.50 for some reason. it works in internal builds
asmodai: a workaround is to use straight characters or NCRs and remove the doctype (which will give better perf in gecko and opera)
Although I guess that may be impractical if your editor doens't support it
(it should, really)
zcorpan: In my case I switched to firemath for creating the first versions of my formulae.
zcorpan: also, that xhtml file is now reworked to html 5. It hardly has any doctype ;)
asmodai: yeah, i meant for the xhtml case
zcorpan: I dropped xhtml in favour of html 5. The latter seems to be much wider implemented, even now. :)
Someone posted http://underdark.nl/dump/ie9-debunk/ in response to the results @ http://samples.msdn.microsoft.com/ietestcenter/
asmodai: mathml in xhtml is implemented in 2 shipping browsers, mathml in html is implemented in 0 shipping browsers, and 1 non-shipping
zcorpan: mathml in html 5 works pretty well in FF 3.6 (when you enable html5 in the config).
asmodai: i count that as non-shipping, but fair enough, 1 shipping browser if you flip a pref
zcorpan: And since it's not public yet, I can limit the exposure. But point taken. But the xhtml route is also wrought with the typical xhtml problems/considered dangerous.
zcorpan: So I guess, by the time it's really in shape to be shown publically html 5 ought to be a bit more in position.
I am still wondering how to do a decent fallback though.
i guess you could detect lack of support and implement a renderer in javascript or something
or parse the html using the js port of the v.nu html parser
zcorpan: Yeah, will think about it some more.
I can so many areas in which MathML could help the research institutes here at uni.
wonders if he can bribe Opera devs with Dutch cheese to get html 5 mathml working
asmodai: try it
likes Dutch cheese
I'll even throw in some french as needed :)
zcorpan: I wonder how easily mathml in html 5 could be made to work with userjs. I remember this whitewolf or what's his name guy who wrote a mathml userjs back in the day
asmodai: it would be easy, but you wouldn't want to apply it for all pages since it'd kill perf
asmodai: http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20080814#l-242
http://underdark.nl/dump/ie9-debunk/ is incorrect on some things though
e.g. border and backgrounds is in CR, which means vendors are encouraged to support properties without prefix
but they don't have to
The presentation of the test results seems intentionally misleading
since it makes it look like IE supports all the standards perfectly
oh yeah, no doubt about that
extremely poor form
only publishing the tests they pass
It's good to have tests and to know what browsers have bugs, but it's silly to compare colour-coded percentages when it's a tiny subset of tests
maybe they didn't make any more tests, but made the impl pass all their tests
Compare http://codedread.com/svg-support.php
where IE gets far less than anything else, on a much wider range of tests
more XMl fun: http://live.visitmix.com/MIX10/Sessions/KEY01 unescaped ampersand
that one loads fine in Opera
so opera and batik 1.7 have "A+"
oh, it's text/html
do you get an A+ for supporting the SVG 1.2 Tiny features that are Bad for the Web?
(XML Events and textArea)
dunno
i think we might have broken xml events while fixing the 'load' event recently
we should probably just remove xml events
zcorpan: how did you fix the load event?
hsivonen: we fired a bubbling event on document before
hsivonen: now we do per spec
I haven't implemeted teh SVG load event at all in text/html, because the SVG WG still hasn't responded to my feedback
zcorpan: sync or async?
hsivonen: how to test?
zcorpan: trying to think of a reliable way...
that graph is bleh
it looks like you could get at best ~70% for not supporting animation
unreliable would be <script>var loadRan =false;</script><svg onload="loadRan=true'></svg><script>alert(loadRan)</script>
the svg testsuite should probably have an order or magnitude more tests anyway to have the coverage we aim for for html5
hsivonen: i get 'false' for that in xhtml
"The following picture indicates the results of running all 280 tests in many popular SVG implementations in the wild."
How much does each test test?
hsivonen: but i don't know if we fire load on svg sync or async
has half an order of magnitude more tests for canvas than that, though a lot of them are testing very similar or very boring things
the interesting number is not how many tests are in a testsuite, but how many bugs are found
But that's a hard number to measure, and it's generally correlated to the number of tests and the extensiveness of each test, which are easier to measure and compare
zcorpan: false means it can't be sync, right? (assuming the onload attribute works)
http://www.readwriteweb.com/archives/npr_and_wsj_building_ipad-only_websites.php

The Wall Street Journal, a News Corp. property, is also building an iPad-only version of their site - well, actually just an iPad-only front page. Unlike NPR's iPad site, which will be 100% Flash-free, WSJ visitors who follow links deeper into the website will soon discover that not all its page have been converted.
hsivonen: yeah, svg load seems to be async
hsivonen: i was talking about the normal window.onload though
zcorpan: ok. I hope the WG agrees with async. I don't want to make it sync.
hsivonen: maybe send an email to ed
zcorpan: I've already sent email to the WG and ed has seen the email
othermaciej: you awake?
hsivonen: ok
hsivonen: have you pointed out that opera fires async?
zcorpan: nope
can't we kill the silly svg load events?
(assuming that is what you're talking about)

http://canvex.lazyilluminati.com/misc/dom-viewer/x.html?%3Chtml%20xmlns%3D'http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2F1999%2Fxhtml'%3E%3Cscript%3EloadRan%3Dfalse%3C%2Fscript%3E%3Csvg%20xmlns%3D'http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3.org%2F2000%2Fsvg'%20onload%3D'loadRan%3Dtrue'%2F%3E%3Cscript%3Ealert(loadRan%3F'sync'%3A'async')%3C%2Fscript%3E%3C%2Fhtml%3E
seems sync in gecko and chrome
ok, I dumped the abstract style sheet concept from CSSOM
style sheets are CSS
as they said in one episode of Better off Ted, deal with it
ah. UA sniffing. a site has one code branch for "Firefox" and another for everything else
and the Firefox branch doesn't work in Gecko+HTML5 parser but the everything else branch works
The web UI for the laundromat here has branches for IE and Netscape
That is, it assumes everything that doesn't have appName Netscape is IE...
isn't that true these days?
or is opera still opera?
oh it is
thought it was changed
is particularly annoyed by people who do if (window.attachEvent) {/*IE + Opera*/} else {/*Everyone else*/}
you could also be annoyed at Opera for implementing support for attachEvent
http://intertwingly.net/blog/2010/03/17/Non-Draconian-XHTML
the xml spec doesn't really require showing an error message
You need to show an error message for debuggability
because otherwise I guess nobody will even realise there's a problem
yeah, I guess you need some text after the error to see what happens
If I look at the MIX site in IE with a faked UA string, then it just stops midway through a news summary with no indication why
*IE9
i think experimental features should be user-opt-in (like webgl and html5 parser in firefox) instead of being ugly syntax
WebGL is opt-in because it's insecure, not because it's experimental
(It has a prefix on the context name because it's experimental)
still, making experimental features being user-opt-in solves the problem of people depending on it
Any sufficiently non-stable release branch does the same, though
yes, not shipping experimental features also works
remembers problems where Facebook(?) depended on experimental features that had only shipped in Firefox betas, and broke when it changed to follow an updated spec
so I guess Firefox betas are insufficiently non-stable
How about this: experimental features only work on intranets :)
That'd make testing hard, since many people don't have intranets
Maybe on experimental.example.org subdomains
Better to do something like force the page's background colour to magenta if it uses experimental features
That wouldn't prevent technical testing of the feature, but would discourage its use in production sites
Oh, oh
It would if the feature was supposed to affect background colour
Make it play a song
Something by crash test dummies, maybe
make the browser crash after a few minutes
jgraham: Those features can change the text colour instead
rofl, on reddit: In honor of St. Patrick's Day, I will drink a beer for every upvote I get!
He now has 1573 upvotes XD
Dashiva: If you want audio, surely it should be a clip of Mr T. saying " I pity the fool who uses experimental features" played at random intervals
No, it has to be sufficiently bad to be discouraging
Mr. T. could easily be seen as a feature
I can imagine a web developer may use a desktop computer with no speakers attached
so they wouldn't discover Mr. T's contributions to their site until they'd launched it and received comments from bemused users
Well then that would teach them to be the fool that used experimental features
hsivonen: i talked with ed and we concluded that it seems most reasonable to remove SVGLoad from most elements but keep it for <svg>, <image> etc, and to make it async
and for <svg> it is delayed like it is delayed for <body>?
at some point someone should work out how that interacts
apparently it is in opera currently, though i don't care if it's async when end tag is parsed or when everything has been parsed
hsivonen: it seems opera doesn't send SVGLoad on elements if there's no <svg> ancestor
hsivonen: another alternative is to kill SVGLoad and make <svg onload> work like <body onload> when it's the root element
zcorpan: killing svg onload would be my preference
if feasible considering compat
hsivonen: i'd prefer killing it as well
thirds
hey all, anyone know how Google Rich Snippets is detecting uF?
if they have code that supports uF and Microdata, that could be helpful for Tantek and other uF tool maintainers
will check logs if anyone can answer that later
boblet, what do you mean "how"?  Presumably Google wrote some software to do it for them, which they haven't released, no?
AryehGregor: how as in a modified version of html5lib, a custom library they wrote, something they’re planning to release, something they’re not planning to release
Why do you assume they made any information public about it?
Their entire search engine and pretty much everything associated with it is closed-source and quite secret, as far as I've seen.
detecting uF and Microdata isn’t exactly secret sauce-level secrets
they have the rich snippet testing tool for testing after all
of course what they do with the data is, but I’m wondering if anyone here has heard about the detecting part
I've heard nothing about the details of any of their rich snippets processing stuff
so the only information I have comes from testing, or from making it up
e.g. it's not using any kind of proper HTML parser (judging by some testing)
Philip`: aah interesting
that prolly means nothing to do with html5lib, and something in-house
and in fact it is powered by snakes that use iPhones (I made that up)
snakes, eh
good to know
wonders how well cold-blooded animals can use touch-sensitive screens
imagines Samuel L. Jackson wandering around the Google server room muttering about motherfucking snakes on motherfucking iPhones
Not that Samuel L. Jackson mutters you understand
Given how Google uses Python
asmodai: so it’s the *snakes* that are programming in Python! of course!! it all becomes clear :)
boblet: :)
asmodai: you truly have deep insight into the workings of things. thank you for enlightening me ;-)
annevk: where did you get the impression that i was cheerleading for h.264?
i have to talk about it in diveintohtml5.org because it's (unfortunately) required to reach all platforms that people would reasonably care about
i think i re-tweeted a mention of IE supporting it because it seemed like big news
that doesn't mean i *like* the fact that web video is standardizing on a patent-encumbered format
(de facto standardizing, not formally standardizing)
then there's the whole "lesser of two evils" thing with naked-H.264-in-a-video-element vs. H.264-played-by-a-Flash-client
indeed. it suddenly becomes easier to scrape websites for content.
seeing as how Flash ships with H.264 plus a bunch of other proprietary stuff (that is not only patent-encumbered but completely vendor-specific and unlicensable under any terms)
and no flash cookies etc.
it seems like a huge win if we can convert all the video sites away from flash
hehe, wake me up when porn sites begin using <video>
or even some of them, some of the time, for some percentage of users
during the most recent html5-vs-flash flamewar, i read that many porn sites have mobile editions which offer pure-H.264-in-MP4 downloads for iPhone and other flash-free platforms
dunno if that's true, but it certainly seems plausible
they're probably doing H.264 encoding anyway to serve up through flash
anyway, video has always been a mess, and it's unrealistic to expect the entire world to shift on a dime and suddenly be non-messy just because we defined a bunch of angle brackets
there was once a post on the Whatwg mailing list about the acces restriction of
Has anybody got the link?
Once?
Pretty sure it's come up several times.
I know I supported that assertion.  Let me look...
it was more written like an article :)
Darn, my gmail-fu is weak.
http://lists.xiph.org/pipermail/theora/2008-November/001958.html that one :)
I tought svg load was only on the svg element
thought
gsnedders: you still around?
MikeSmith: As of about 20 minutes ago he was out
Erm
Semantics fail
ok
I mean "20 minutes ago, when my information was last known to be correct, he was out"
jgraham: understood, thanks

mpilgrim: Arguably, for a new entrant to the browser market, H.264 is worse than Flash because the barrier to entry of millions of dollars a year for licenses is a greater impediment than the need to implement the Netscape plugin API and let adobe worry about licenses
(for end users it is better as long as they don't mind browsers requiring large companies backing them and don't care about open source or small players)
jgraham: Decoder distribution licenses, you mean?
Yes
That's pretty much an OS feature by now, though
If you don't care about small players or new entrants
And if the media backend on the OS has the APIs you need for the particular requirments of web video
That seems to be the case for all major OSes at the moment
My understanding is that it is non-trivial to get good support in some cases
using the native APIs
(especially if you are not the OS vendor and can't change / fix the APIs / codecs as needed)
(and for Linux it is only the case that you can play H.264 if you ignore the laws that prevent you doing so)
+ other OSes that don't license the codecs correctly
This is all very vague and ominous
Dashiva: Not really
I guess "it's possible to just use the platform-supplied codecs and push the licensing concerns onto someone else" is a valid counter argument
But there are real disadvantages
jgraham: sounds similar to "It's possible to just use the flash-supplied codecs and push the licensing concerns onto someone else"
Dashiva: You probably have to implement NPAPI anyway and it is probably mostly shared between platforms whilst video would need N implementations to ship on N platforms
Oh, sure, it's more work. But it's just another feature to support, there's nothing inherently harder about it.
i love feedback that just says "Section 1.2.3, step 4 should be changed to do X because Y" where X and Y assume you know what section 1.2.3 step 4 is.
tries to parse
Oh

given that there are over a dozen specs each with different section numbers, several of which are the same text, and all of which change regularly, and given that i only look at feedback with a latency of a few months...
Dashiva, Windows doesn't have H.264 codecs installed by default before Windows 7, as far as I've heard.
And it's true that Linux only does on the theory of "downloading my distribution copy of ffmpeg-nonfree isn't pirating, honest".
Okay, who has any idea what might be the issue here?  http://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Special:Code/MediaWiki/63842
I'm not sure what would cause Mac and Windows Firefox to treat px differently.  Different DPI settings or something?
Maybe they use different baselines to offset from
othermaciej: would be good to have some webkit feedback on http://lists.whatwg.org/pipermail/whatwg-whatwg.org/2010-March/025403.html
annevk: opera feedback too ^
Hixie: it looks to me like that message is itself WebKit feedback
true
annevk! opera's feedback would be most welcome :-)
AryehGregor: we've heard that Microsoft is going to ship an H.264 codec in Vista SP2
a lot of XP users will upgrade to Windows 7 relatively soon, but there will probably be a very long tail of XP users too
